description:
Software/Engineering/Computers can be intimidating.  As we embark on this journey we will be putting each one of you outside of your comfort zones.  The best thing to do when feeling vulnerable is to embrace and conquer the fear.  We've conditioned ourselves to accept failure as a negative thing.  We've automatically closed off the ability for our minds to grow because we are scared that we don't have the "right" answer. 

Success without failure and experimentation is lost quickly.  Experimentation, failure, refinement are all vital aspects of success even though we don't count it as the currency to measure success.  The advice I can give you is to be curious, explore, and fail often.  With each failure, we will learn as individuals, and share our failures with the group so that we can arrive at success as soon as possible. Overcoming our fear of failure will give us the tools to make our environment a special learning environment.

That said, use this time to think about the following Getting Started Introspection.  Use the questions to guide you to think about what your goals and aspirations are. 

 

Helpful Resources 

https://medium.com/@PaulDJohnston/why-you-should-always-ask-why-in-programming-88eb41419c82#.vgiqr6xeb

https://tylergarlick.com/learning-to-embrace-failures-ecb13733c631#.cyu6qd8if
name: Getting Started in Software Engineering

description:
Resources

Assignment
name: Using data structures to organize data

rubric.description: Using data structures to organize data
rubric.long_description:
Learner must:

  1. Understand the different types of data structures
    1. Create a stack and implement the appropriate methods
    2. Create a queue  and implement the appropriate methods
    3. Create a linked list  and implement the appropriate methods
    4. Create a double linked list  and implement the appropriate methods
    5. Create a tree  and implement the appropriate methods
  2. Understand when to use the different data types

rubric_settings.title: Using data structures to organize  data

description:
Welcome!

What an epic journey we are about to embark!!  There are many misconceptions about software/engineering/computers/etc.  I often chuckle at the things that people say when I tell them that you can learn how to do (insert skill here) and change your life.  To lots, it's an incredible journey and won't have the courage to start.  Guess what?!? You've chosen to take that trip.  I'm excited for you.  It's a very exciting and rewarding journey!

As we embark on this journey, we will be putting each one of you outside of your comfort zones.  The best thing to do when feeling vulnerable is to embrace and conquer the fear.  We've conditioned ourselves to accept failure as a negative thing.  We've automatically closed off the ability for our minds to grow because we are scared that we don't have the "right" answer. 

Success without failure and experimentation is lost quickly.  Experimentation, failure, refinement are all vital aspects of success even though we don't count it as the currency to measure success.  The advice I can give you is to be curious, explore, and fail often.  With each failure, we will learn as individuals and share our failures with the group so that we can arrive at success as soon as possible. Overcoming our fear of failure will give us the tools to make our environment an extraordinary learning atmosphere.

 

That said, use this time to think about the questions below.  Use the questions to guide you and introspect about what your goals are in the class.

Questions

  • What are your goals for this class?
    • What will you do to ensure you met your goals?
  • Beginning with the end in mind, what is your desired outcome of the course? And career?
    • What steps can you take to start working on that goal now?
  • What is the biggest problem you've overcome?  How did you do it?
  • What is a fun fact about you?
  • What will your coding/programming name be? (Granted some of them come over time, it's always fun to have a programming name)

 

Helpful Resources

  • https://medium.com/@PaulDJohnston/why-you-should-always-ask-why-in-programming-88eb41419c82#.vgiqr6xeb
  • https://tylergarlick.com/learning-to-embrace-failures-ecb13733c631#.cyu6qd8if
name: Welcome to our Journey

discussion_topic.title: Welcome to our Journey
discussion_topic.message:
Welcome!

What an epic journey we are about to embark!!  There are many misconceptions about software/engineering/computers/etc.  I often chuckle at the things that people say when I tell them that you can learn how to do (insert skill here) and change your life.  To lots, it's an incredible journey and won't have the courage to start.  Guess what?!? You've chosen to take that trip.  I'm excited for you.  It's a very exciting and rewarding journey!

As we embark on this journey, we will be putting each one of you outside of your comfort zones.  The best thing to do when feeling vulnerable is to embrace and conquer the fear.  We've conditioned ourselves to accept failure as a negative thing.  We've automatically closed off the ability for our minds to grow because we are scared that we don't have the "right" answer. 

Success without failure and experimentation is lost quickly.  Experimentation, failure, refinement are all vital aspects of success even though we don't count it as the currency to measure success.  The advice I can give you is to be curious, explore, and fail often.  With each failure, we will learn as individuals and share our failures with the group so that we can arrive at success as soon as possible. Overcoming our fear of failure will give us the tools to make our environment an extraordinary learning atmosphere.

 

That said, use this time to think about the questions below.  Use the questions to guide you and introspect about what your goals are in the class.

Questions

  • What are your goals for this class?
    • What will you do to ensure you met your goals?
  • Beginning with the end in mind, what is your desired outcome of the course? And career?
    • What steps can you take to start working on that goal now?
  • What is the biggest problem you've overcome?  How did you do it?
  • What is a fun fact about you?
  • What will your coding/programming name be? (Granted some of them come over time, it's always fun to have a programming name)

 

Helpful Resources

  • https://medium.com/@PaulDJohnston/why-you-should-always-ask-why-in-programming-88eb41419c82#.vgiqr6xeb

description:
Answer the following questions:

  1. How do you call a function?
  2. What do you call the pieces inside of the parenthesis when you define a function?
  3. When you call a function what do you call the pieces in the parenthesis?
  4. Can functions take variable parameters? How?
  5. Can you overload a function (this means can you have an add function that takes two parameters, then redefine it underneath and the add function takes 3 parameters, see https://gist.github.com/TylerGarlick/be409ec02c2fb65d837ae097460571bd)?(Links to an external site.)

description:
Command line primer for beginners on Unix/Max using Bash: http://lifehacker.com/5633909/who-needs-a-mouse-learn-to-use-the-command-line-for-almost-anything

How to install the bash shell on Windows 10: http://www.windowscentral.com/how-install-bash-shell-command-line-windows-10

 To get credit for this competency, demonstrate your ability to navigate, create, and execute shell scripts using the terminal or command line to an instructor or course mentor.
name: Use basic Bash/Terminal commands

rubric.long_description:
Learner is able to use Bash commands to:

  1. list all files in a directory including hidden files
  2. navigate up and down a directory structure
  3. redirect and pipe output between processes
  4. execute scripts from the terminal
  5. determine their network interfaces and IP address
  6. identify and edit environment and profile (e.g. .bash_profile) settings
  7. install software packages
  8. write and execute a custom script

description:
Demonstrate that you can use the Angular CLI to create and run a simple web application that uses Angular 2.

You can see an example project here: https://github.com/helio-training/angular-hello-world

To provide proof of competency:

  1. Create an Angular app using the CLI
  2. Create a ReadMe.md file for your app that describes what it does and how to run it.
  3. Be sure your app can be installed and run and then commit and push it to your repo.
  4. Provide the commit URL for this competency as your assignment submission in Canvas.
  5. Post your thoughts to this forum: Why would the Angular team choose TypeScript?
name: Install and use the Angular CLI to create and run a web application

rubric.description: Use Angular CLI to create and run app
rubric.long_description:
The learner will be able to:

  • Create a simple Angular web app using the CLI
  • Create a ReadMe.md file describing what the app does and how to install/run it
  • Commit and push this web app to an online repository

rubric_settings.title: Use Angular CLI to create app

description:
Respond to this discussion forum question:

What is the purpose of source version control?

Practice using Git following these step-by-step commands that Korvyn laid out:

Git Commands

Practice using a simplified GitFlow-style process by following the instructions at this repo:

https://github.com/thortek/DGM3780-Assign1(Links to an external site.)(Links to an external site.)

Obtain the completion badge at Code School's git course (https://www.codeschool.com/courses/git-real(Links to an external site.).

Submit the badge's url to this assignment.
name: Perform basic Git operations

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. describe the role and value of version control in software development
  2. configure Git user settings
  3. initialize a local Git repository
  4. clone a remote repository
  5. stage files, commit, revert and stash a commit
  6. display the git log
  7. push and pull from remote repo

description:
Take this course on Pluralsight "How Git Works" https://app.pluralsight.com/library/courses/how-git-works/table-of-contents

Git Tutorial: Rebasing and Merging: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a_msiOrYLgM

How to create .gitignore files: https://help.github.com/articles/ignoring-files/

How to manually fix git merge conflicts: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g8BRcB9NLp4

Atlassian tutorial on GitFlow: https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow

Obtain the course badge from CodeSchool's course (https://www.codeschool.com/courses/git-real-2(Links to an external site.)) and submit the badge's url to this assignment.
name: Perform intermediate Git operations

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. create feature branches and rebase/merge a trunk branch into feature branch
  2. create and merge pull requests
  3. create an appropriate .gitignore file
  4. diff files and resolve merge conflicts with a GUI tool but also through manual editing of the conflicted file
  5. execute soft and hard resets
  6. use a basic GitFlow process

description:
The learner is able to use JavaScript 2015 modules to encapsulate and reuse functionality.

  1. Pre-Work View the following Pluralsight course: https://www.pluralsight.com/courses/javascript-module-fundamentals
  2. Complete the module practice assignment here: https://github.com/helio-training/full-stack-javascript-assignments/tree/solutions/src/javascript/intro/001-modules/importing-and-exporting
  3. After completing the module assignment, post your Github submission URL as proof of competency.
  4. Post your responses to the modules discussion forum for participation credit.

The learner is able to create and run JavaScript compile and build tasks

  1. Pre-Work View the following Pluralsight course: https://app.pluralsight.com/library/courses/npm-build-tool-introduction/table-of-contents
  2. Complete the compile and build practice assignment here:
  3. After completing the compile and build assignment, post your Github submission URL as proof of competency.
  4. Post your responses to the _________________ discussion forum for participation credit.
name: Use modules to encapsulate and reuse funtionality - use NPM for compile and build tasks

rubric.description: Use JavaScript build tools and modules
rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Use JavaScript2015 modules to encapsulate and reuse functionality
  2. Create and run JavaScript compile and build tasks (e.g. Grunt, Gulp, WebPack)

description: Demonstrate proficiency to an instructor, or mentor.
name: Install and configure IDE or text editor

rubric.description: Install and configure IDE or text editor
rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. install and configure an IDE (e.g. Webstorm) or text editor (e.g. VS Code)
  2. configure IDE to show syntax errors and JS linting errors
  3. configure and use autocompletion and other productivity enhancers
  4. configure IDE to execute local servers and other processes
  5. identify differences between IDEs and text editors
  6. configure and use debugging capabilities
  7. configure and use appropriate extensions

rubric_settings.title: Install and configure IDE or text editor

name: Begin using JavaScript

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. create and load a JavaScript file into an execution environment such as Node or a browser
  2. find their way around proper (e.g. MDN) documentation
  3. comment individual and block comments
  4. demonstrate how to output results using alert() and console.log() to assist with debugging
  5. declare and initialize variables
  6. demonstrate understanding of "operators" concept
  7. perform simple tasks using operators and assign the results to variables

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Use CSS to style HTML elements

rubric.description: Use CSS to style HTML elements
rubric.long_description:
Learner will be able to:

  1. Apply styles using inline, internal, and external style sheets
  2. Use the class, id, element, and universal selectors
  3. Use more complex CSS selectors including:
    1. attribute selectors
    2. pseudo-classes
    3. pseudo-elements
    4. combinators
    5. multiple selectors
  4. Include CSS written by others into their pages

rubric_settings.title: Use CSS to style HTML elements

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. use blocks to group statements
  2. use if... else and switch statements
  3. throw exceptions using throw statement
  4. use try... catch block to respond and catch thrown exceptions

name: Deploy a full stack web app

rubric.description: Deploy a full stack web app
rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Choose proper file transfer options for deployment (e.g. Git, FTP, SCP, rsync)
  2. Compile app using build tools to deploy and test locally
  3. Deploy full stack app to hosted service (e.g. Heroku, AWS, Azure)
  4. Explain continuous integration and how it is used (e.g. TravisCI, Jenkins)
  5. Describe how an app can run on multiple servers at once
  6. Explain the purpose and value of load balancers and load testing

rubric_settings.title: Deploy a full stack web app

name: Create client-side automated tests

rubric.long_description:
Learner will be able to:

  1. Explain the purpose and value of Test Driven Development
  2. Install and use a test framework to write basic tests (e.g. Jasmine)
  3. Setup and run unit tests using a test runner (e.g. Karma)
  4. Write and run end-to-end (e2e) user experience tests (e.g. Protractor)
  5. Identify and demonstrate unit, end-to-end, and regression/integration testing

  2. Start, stop, and restart the server
  3. Read the Request object and use its properties
  4. Use the Response object to reply including header and status codes
  5. Inspect the Request/Response objects using browser developer tools

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. Create collections and documents
  2. Use the insert commands to add documents to a collection
  3. Find and read documents in collections using the various find methods
  4. Add query filters to find documents which meet the query criteria
  5. Use update operations to update documents
  6. Remove documents from collections using the delete commands

rubric_settings.title: Use JavaScript build tools and modules

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Utilize Express middleware

rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Effectively use common middleware such as body-parser
  2. Use middleware to do authentication/authorization and error handling (e.g. Passport)
  3. Implement a sessions API using cookies
  4. Implement a session store in the backend (e.g. MemoryStore, RedisStore, or MongoStore)

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Create server-side automated tests

rubric.long_description:
Learner is able to:

  1. Install and run a server-side JS testing framework (e.g. Mocha)
  2. Install and write tests using an expectation library (e.g. Assert, Chai, Expect.js)
  3. Describe and use 'Behavior Driven Development' (BDD)

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Employ advanced CSS techniques

rubric.long_description:
The learner will be able to:

  1. Use CSS animations properly and where appropriate
  2. Use transitions to good effect
  3. Create floated features such as drop caps, floated images, and multiple column layouts
  4. Tailor content to a range of output devices using media queries
  5. Use flexbox to overcome issues with float layout

description:
Resources

Great resource on doing Object-Oriented JavaScript using ES2015: https://app.pluralsight.com/library/courses/javascript-es6-object-oriented-programming/table-of-contents(Links to an external site.)

Watch these 2 modules from Mark Zamoyta's course "Rapid JavaScript Training":

  • Introduction(Links to an external site.)
  • Simple Objects and JSON(Links to an external site.)

 

Assignment

https://github.com/helio-training/full-stack-javascript-assignments/tree/master/src/javascript/basics/objects/object-literals(Links to an external site.)

 

Submission

Submit the url of your assignment to github.

Answer the following questions: Object Literals
name: Create and use Objects

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. create new objects using object initializers and constructor functions
  2. define properties and methods of an object
  3. use "this" for object references
  4. define getters and setters for an object
  5. compare objects for equality
  6. explain concept of "object" within JavaScript
  7. explain differences between "class-based" and "prototype-based" languages

description:
Pre-Work

Some useful JavaScript function snippets from Tyler: https://github.com/helio-training/js-snippets/blob/master/functions/index.js(Links to an external site.)

Assignment

Fork and clone: https://github.com/helio-training/fs-corejs-functions-basics(Links to an external site.)

Submission

Submit a commit URL from your GitHub site that points to your code/project which demonstrates mastery of this competency.

Answer the following questions: Define and use functions
name: Define and use functions

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. create function definitions
  2. create function expressions including anonymous ones
  3. properly call functions
  4. demonstrate nested functions and closures
  5. use the arguments object
  6. demonstrate function parameters including default ones
  7. use Arrow functions

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Create RESTful APIs using routes

rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Use the Express router to create modular, mountable route handlers
  2. Specify and use different routes based on pattern matching
  3. Define and use route parameters (named URL segments)
  4. Use route handlers (multiple callback functions that behave like middleware) to handle a request
  5. Explain what makes an API endpoint RESTful

description:
Nice explanation and guide here on the NodeJS docs site explaining how to build a simple web server using Node: https://nodejs.org/en/docs/guides/anatomy-of-an-http-transaction/

 

Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Build a NodeJS web server

rubric.long_description:
The learner will be able to:

  1. Demonstrate a solid understanding of how HTTP works
  2. Compose an HTTP request and get a response from their server
  3. Create HTTP responses with headers and status codes
  4. Respond to HTTP requests with text, HTML, or JSON

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Layout an HTML5 web page

rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Structure a valid document using html, head, title, body and script tags
  2. Properly use a broad mix of html5 elements and attributes
  3. Link to other pages and to named anchors within a web page
  4. Include images and comments in a page
  5. Create HTML5 tables to display tabular data
  6. Create a basic form and submit the form data
  7. Use advanced HTML5 elements such as Canvas and Video

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Apply the Box Model for element layout

rubric.description: Apply the Box Model for element layout
rubric.long_description:
Learner will be able to:

  1. Manipulate height, width, margin, border, and padding properties to achieve desired element layouts
  2. Use the display property (block, inline, inline-block) to effect element layout
  3. Utilize box shadows and the filter property to enhance UI elements

rubric_settings.title: Apply the Box Model for element layout

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Troubleshoot and debug common errors

rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Open and use the Chrome developer tools
  2. Debug with Firefox and Edge developer tools
  3. Create breakpoints and step into and over code blocks
  4. Create watch expressions and conditional breakpoints
  5. Identify logic errors in pieces of code by using the debugger

description:
Pre-Work

  • https://medium.com/javascript-scene/master-the-javascript-interview-what-is-a-closure-b2f0d2152b36#.vaylhd14o
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Hoisting
  • http://www.adequatelygood.com/JavaScript-Scoping-and-Hoisting.html
  • https://app.pluralsight.com/player?course=advanced-javascript&author=kyle-simpson&name=advanced-javascript-m2&clip=0

Submission

Submit a commit URL from your GitHub site that points to your code/project which demonstrates mastery of this competency.

Answer the following questions: Understanding scope, hoisting, and closures
name: Understanding scope, hoisting, and closures

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. describe local and global scope using examples of functions, variables, and objects
  2. demonstrate hoisting and how code order effects flow
  3. demonstrate practical use of JavaScript closures

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Use Express scaffolding and view engines

rubric.description: Use Express scaffolding and view engines
rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Use a scaffolder (e.g. Yeoman) to layout an Express application
  2. Utilize an appropriate view engine (e.g. Pug) to serve static files

rubric_settings.title: Use Express scaffolding and view engines

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Troubleshoot advanced errors

rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Interpret complex console errors
  2. Examine and debug network requests
  3. Use online resources when encountering complex errors (e.g. Google, Stack Overflow)

description:
NodeJS documentation on events in Node: https://nodejs.org/api/events.html

 

Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Respond to NodeJS events

rubric.long_description:
The learner will be able to:

  1. Explain the event-driven architecture behind NodeJS
  2. Create events and use EventEmitter to emit them
  3. Handle emitted events including 'error' events

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Explain key Angular 2 concepts

rubric.long_description:
The learner can:

  1. Describe how Angular 2 uses expressive HTML
  2. Explain the purpose and usage of Angular 2 data binding
  3. Relate how Angular 2 is modular by design
  4. Describe how Angular 2 integrates with back-end services
  5. Explain the overall architecture of an Angular 2 application

description:
Here is the official site for all things related to MongoDB: https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/

 

Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Install, start and connect to MongoDB

rubric.description: Install, start and connect to MongoDB
rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. Install the MongoDB server
  2. Start and stop MongoDB using the mongod process
  3. Connect to MongoDB using NodeJS

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Create functional Angular 2 components

rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Properly import required core Angular components 
  2. Implement the @Component decorator
  3. Properly define component properties using selector, moduleId, templateUrl, and styleUrls
  4. Properly define component methods that respond to events in the view
  5. Properly implement existing interfaces
  6. Define and use custom interfaces
  7. Export defined component for use in other modules

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Implement routing and navigation

rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Choose between using a nested component or a route
  2. Configure routes using RouterModule
  3. Define URL segments for specific routes and also the default and wildcard routes
  4. Connect routes to actions using the RouterLink directive
  5. Use the RouterOutlet directive to display the routed component's view
  6. Pass parameters to a route using the ActivatedRoute service
  7. Navigate to routes programmatically using Router.navigate()

description:
Go to Mark Zamoyta's course "Rapid JavaScript Training" on Pluralsight.

Watch the following video segments:

  • Introduction
  • Understanding Reference Types
  • Reference Type Examples
  • Array Fundamentals

Complete the "Arrays with Simple Types" assignment found here: https://github.com/helio-training/full-stack-javascript-assignments/tree/solutions/src/javascript/basics/arrays/001-simple-types

Gain participation points by posting to this discussion forum about arrays: Arrays with Simple Types

Submit commit URL(s) from your GitHub account that point to your code/project which demonstrates mastery of this competency.
name: Manipulate data in Arrays

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. store various types of data in Arrays
  2. retrieve data from precise locations in an Array
  3. retrieve subsets of data from an Array
  4. combine, copy, add items and subtract from an Array

description:
Assignment

https://github.com/helio-training/full-stack-javascript-assignments/tree/master/src/javascript/intro/grammer/strings(Links to an external site.)

 

Submission

Submit a commit URL from your GitHub site that points to your code/project which demonstrates mastery of this competency.

Answer the following questions: Strings and Regular expressions
name: Manipulate Strings and Regular expressions

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. use the String object, it's length property, and its methods (e.g. indexOf, match, trim) to manipulate String data
  2. understand proper use of String literals
  3. write simple Regular expressions
  4. use the exec() method to search for a match in a string

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Use data binding and pipes

rubric.long_description:
The learner is able to:

  1. Use interpolation {{}} style property binding
  2. Use property binding [ ] style to link class with DOM
  3. Implement two-way data binding using ngModel
  4. Use default Angular pipes to filter data
  5. Create and use a custom pipe to filter data in a specific manner

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Use services to retrieve data

rubric.long_description:
Learner will be able to:

  1. Build Angular 2 services using the @Injectable decorator
  2. Register a service class provider in a component's metadata

description:
Assignment

Provide an example of all the different types of data types that javascript has.https://github.com/helio-training/full-stack-javascript-assignments/tree/master/src/javascript/intro/grammer/typings(Links to an external site.)

 

 

Submission

Submit a commit URL from your GitHub site that points to your code/project which demonstrates mastery of this competency.

Answer the following questions: Use types, variables and primitives

 

 

Resources

https://medium.com/javascript-scene/javascript-es6-var-let-or-const-ba58b8dcde75#.wq83s93u2(Links to an external site.)

https://hackernoon.com/why-you-shouldnt-use-var-anymore-f109a58b9b70#.ejryxyp79(Links to an external site.)
name: Use types, keywords, and primitives to structure applications

rubric.description: Use data types, keywords, and primitives
rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. demonstrate proper use of JavaScript primitives
  2. explain and demonstrate type conversion
  3. explain and demonstrate writing statements using keywords and primitives
  4. explain literals to represent values in JavaScript
  5. explain difference between using primitives and using an Object that acts as a wrapper around the primitive data type (e.g. Boolean)

rubric_settings.title: Use types, keywords and primitives to structure applications Rubric

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Utilize dependency injection

rubric.long_description:
Learner will be able to:

  1. Use injected service instances using constructor parameters
  2. Utilize a lifecyle hook method such as ngOnInit() to call injected service methods

name: Use Date, Number, and Math objects

rubric.description: Use Date, Number, and Math objects
rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. create and format Dates and parse them from strings
  2. use the built-in Number object's properties and methods
  3. use the built-in Math object's properties and methods

rubric_settings.title: Use Date, Number, and Math objects

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub repo to demonstrate mastery of this competency.
name: Compose applications using modules

rubric.long_description:
Learner will be able to:

  1. Use ES 2015 modules in combination with Angular 2 modules
  2. Nest components within other components using @Input and @Output decorators
  3. Create Angular 2 modules using the NgModule decorator
  4. Import and export modules including feature and shared modules

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub site that points to your code/project which demonstrates mastery of this competency.
name: Use events, callbacks, and promises

rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. discriminate between synchronous and async events and understand the complexity of async
  2. use callbacks to run after a function is completed
  3. use promises in place of callbacks

description: Submit a commit URL from your GitHub site that points to your code/project which demonstrates mastery of this competency.
name: Use loops to iterate over Arrays and Objects

rubric.description: Use loops to iterate over Arrays and Objects
rubric.long_description:
Learner must be able to:

  1. explain and use for, for...in, and for...of statements to interate over an array or object
  2. use the while and do... while statements while a condition is true
  3. explain the labeled, break, and continue statements
  4. nest loops to traverse a multi-dimensional array

rubric_settings.title: Use loops to iterate over Arrays and Objects

description:
Resources

Mark Zamoyta's course "Object-oriented Programming in JavaScript - ES6":

  • Introduction(Links to an external site.)
  • Creating the Start-up Module(Links to an external site.)
  • Defining Classes and Objects(Links to an external site.)
  • Class Creation(Links to an external site.)
  • Constructors and Properties(Links to an external site.)
  • Static Properties(Links to an external site.)
  • Methods(Links to an external site.)
  • Static Methods(Links to an external site.)
  • Getters and Setters(Links to an external site.)
  • Summary(Links to an external site.)

 

Assignment

Complete this assignment creating and using Objects with a Class: https://github.com/helio-training/fs-corejs-objects-basics/tree/master/docs/classes/class-keyword

Submission

To gain participation points, post your thoughts to this discussion forum: Objects with a Class

Submit GitHub commit URL(s) pointing to your code/project which demonstrates mastery of this competency.
name: Classes and introductory OOP

rubric.long_description:
A learner should be able to:

  1. Understand the difference between a class and object literal
  2. Use a class to create multiple objects
  3. Understand 3 ways to create objects:
    1. Class
    2. Literal
    3. Object.create()
  4. Use inheritance to build relationships between objects

rubric_settings.title: Use OOP to build application Rubric

name: Use async/await to control parallelism

rubric.long_description: Learner will be able to:

A learner must be able to:
